skill.name: worldview-synthesis
skill.description: This skill should be used when someone wants to articulate, explore, or document their personal worldview, values, or philosophy. Triggers on "articulate my values", "figure out what I believe", "document my philosophy", "write a manifesto", "define my leadership philosophy", "explore my beliefs". Surfaces beliefs through systematic interrogation, identifies tensions, and generates narrative outputs.

skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code, no file access, no network calls, and no external command execution. Contains only methodology instructions and question templates for personal reflection.

content.user_title: Explore and articulate your personal worldview
content.value_statement: People struggle to articulate what they believe and why. This skill guides users through systematic questioning to surface core values, identify contradictions, and generate shareable narratives from mission statements to full essays.
actual_capabilities: Guide users through 6 rounds of structured personal questions
Identify tensions and productive paradoxes in beliefs
Generate narratives at ascending scales (mission to full essay)
Apply YAML schema to organize beliefs as a knowledge graph
Provide ready-to-use interrogation questions across 20+ life domains
limitations: Does not execute code or access files on your system
Does not connect to external APIs or services
Requires user to provide honest answers for meaningful results
Output quality depends on user engagement and self-reflection depth

use_cases.title: Define leadership philosophy
use_cases.description: Articulate core values for team culture and decision-making frameworks

use_cases.title: Write authentic manifestos
use_cases.description: Create mission statements and manifestos that sound like you

use_cases.title: Clarify company values
use_cases.description: Document personal beliefs that shape company culture and ethics

prompt_templates.title: Quick values check
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me quickly identify my top 5 core values using the AskUserQuestion tool with 2 options each.

prompt_templates.title: Full exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me through a complete worldview synthesis session. Start by asking about my influences, then run 4-6 rounds of interrogation questions, capture tensions, and generate a mission statement.

prompt_templates.title: Company values
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me articulate my personal values to define company culture. Use questions about leadership, ethics, and decision-making to extract my core beliefs.

prompt_templates.title: Tension surfacing
prompt_templates.prompt: Run interrogation rounds focused on money, competition, trust, and conflict. Help me identify where my beliefs contradict each other and name those tensions clearly.

output_examples.input: Help me articulate my values and write a personal mission statement
output: Core Thesis: One sentence capturing your fundamental worldview
Mission Statement: 100 words with 5-7 guiding principles
Softer Truths: Areas where you extend grace

best_practices: Start with sources (books, people, experiences) before diving into direct questions
Push past comfort zones to death, money, conflict, and ethics
Name tensions explicitly rather than trying to resolve contradictions away
anti_patterns: Accepting vague should beliefs without probing for actual behavior
Allowing users to claim they have no worldview (everyone does)
Resolving tensions instead of naming and embracing productive paradoxes

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for structured reflection sessions.

faq.question: How long does a full session take?
faq.answer: A complete worldview synthesis takes 60-90 minutes including 4-6 interrogation rounds.

faq.question: Can I use this for team alignment?
faq.answer: Yes, use individual outputs to find common values and tensions across team members.

faq.question: Is my data stored anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides prompts and structure. Your answers stay in the conversation.

faq.question: Why are tensions important?
faq.answer: Tensions reveal where you hold multiple valid truths. They make your worldview authentic rather than simplified.

faq.question: How is this different from values exercises?
faq.answer: It treats worldview as a graph with tensions, not a flat list. It explicitly surfaces contradictions.
